choices.text: Fat free TPN will be given in future
The reason for this problem is Fat in the TPN
Permanently TPN will be avoided for him

questions.text: Mr Kumar, a case of Short Bowel syndrome was on treatment with Total parenteral nutrition for more than 1 year. Now he suddenly developed Jaundice. On LFT evaluation- SGOT/SGPT is elevated. Which of the following is false regarding management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a clinical scenario in which patient developed Fatty liver and hepatic steatosis due to overfeeding with Fat containing TPN.
  • This is the most common cause for jaundice in patients with TPN for long term
  • We have temporarily stop the regular TPN and restart fat free TPN ( 3:1 ratio of Carbohydrate and Protein) for these patients
  • Very long term TPN may lead to Liver failure also and that is one of the most common indication for Combined Small bowel+ Liver transplant.

choices.text: Hormones activated in EBB phase are Catecholamines, Cortisol and Aldosterone
Catabolic phase of Flow model is associated with increased Growth hormone

questions.solution: • This model explains what happens in Trauma and Stress/ surgery for a patient:

questions.text: A surgeon completed Modified radical mastectomy. He asks the junior resident to complete the surgery. Which of the following suture material is used to put Subcuticular sutures by the resident?
questions.solution:
• Monocryl is Polyglycaprone.
  • People call it as white vicryl
  • It is a monofilament material and most commonly used for subcuticular sutures nowadays

questions.text: Mrs Kumari underwent gastrectomy for carcinoma stomach- and abdomen closure was planned. The laparotomy wound length was measured. It is 15 cm in length. The surgeon now decides to close the abdomen using a Prolene 1' size. What should be the minimum length of the suture to close the abdomen wound.
questions.solution: • As per Jenkin rule- the length of suture must be ideally 4 times the length of the wound.

questions.text: Mrs Kumari underwent gastrectomy for carcinoma stomach- and abdomen closure was planned. The laparotomy wound length was measured. It is 15 cm in length. The surgeon now decides to close the abdomen using a Prolene 1' size. What should be the minimum length of the suture to close the abdomen wound.
questions.solution:
• Blended- Mixture of Continuous and Damped Sine wave.
  • More continuous will have more cutting and more damped will have more coagulation
  • Blend 1 50:50
  • Blend 2 40:60
  • Blend 3 25:75 ( More coagulating)

questions.text: A patient named Mr Ramu was operate for a inguinal hernia by laparoscopic method, by TAPP method comes to you with abdominal distension, guarding and rigidity on 3rd POD. During Laparoscopy the surgeon has touched the needle holder with diathermy. At that time needle holder was in contact with Bowel. QWhat problem might have happened during surgery based on above line
10 years after hysterectomy patient presents with fever and loin pain. The problem happened in WHO Surgical Safety list during
questions.solution:
• The image shows a missed pad. During Sign out of WHO protocol , the Staff nurse had not given the correct number and the surgeon hence missed a pad.
  • This is medico legal case , hence sign out must be done seriously after surgery

choices.text: Surgery planned has an expected time < 2 hours
Journey time from home is 2 hours
No upper limit for age- can be done at any age

questions.text: Mr kumar was planned for Day case surgery. Which of the following factor given below will make him unfit for Day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Points from Bailey

  • BP < 180/110 need not be cancelled from Day care list
  • Hba1c < 8.5% is good control
  • Epilepsy is not a contraindication for surgery- but don’t omit the tablets preoperatively
  • BMI upto 40 for Surface procedures, upto 38 for laparoscopic procedures are acceptable
  • Travel Time < 1 hour
  • Surgery Time < 2 Hours

questions.text: Mr Gupta 30 years male faced a massive road traffic accident and was admitted in ICU for multiple fractures. He was planned for Damage Control Surgery based on the following facts. Which among the following parameter is not an indication for Damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
5 Stages of DCS

  • 1- Identify the patient
  • 2- Emergency OT
  • 3- ICU care
  • 4- Elective repairs
  • 5- Closure of abdomen

choices.text: 4 people needed to do the test
Per rectal examination is done to look for anal sphincter reflex
Log roll is a part of secondary survey

questions.text: A patient was admitted following a RTA. Casualty team wanted to do Log roll. False regarding LOG ROLL examination
questions.solution:
• Log roll is a part of primary survey.
  • It is not advised nowadays due to wastage of time in arranging the 4 people and doing the test.
  • Whole body CT is advised for major trauma nowadays and this has replaced Logroll
  • Please remember Log roll is done to prevent spine injuries while moving the patient and examining the back
  • Never forget to do Per rectal examination when doing the test.
  • PR is done for anal sphincter reflex and to look for any prostate floating( Vermooten sign in membranous urethral injury)

choices.text: Right upper quadrant Longitudinal view is used
Left Upper quadrant Transverse view is used
Suprapubic- both Longitudinal and Transverse view is used

questions.text: Regarding the PROBE views in e- FAST - False statement is
questions.solution:
• The probe placement while doing e FAST is shown here:
  • Subxiphoid transverse view
  • Right and Left Hypochondrium must have longitudinal view
  • Suprapubic both Longitudinal and transverse view

Demerits of E fast:

  • Can detect more than 100 ml blood only *( Bailey)
  • Not detects Hollow viscus injury
  • Not useful for Penetrating Injury
  • Unreliable to detect retroperitoneal injuries
  • Operator dependent

choices.text: Repeat intubation using gum elastic bougie.
Usage of a Laryngeal Mask/ Laryngeal Tube airway.

questions.text: A 60 year old gentleman is brought to a trauma center with H/O polytrauma. He is unable to give a verbal response to your question. O/E you note that he has laryngeal crepitus. Suspecting Airway compromise, Intubation was planned. But there is difficulty in intubation in two successive attempts. You note that, there is a fall in saturation in between intubation attempts. What will be the ideal airway in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is unable to give a verbal response. It indicates some obstruction to airflow or mental status depression. Hence he needs an airway management.
  • Fall in Saturation in between two intubation attempts is an Indication for Surgical airway.
  • Since this patient also has Laryngeal crepitus, he might be having injury in the cricothyroid region, hence Tracheostomy which is also a surgical airway will be the ideal airway for him.
  • Surgical airways - Cricothyroidotomy and Tracheostomy
  • Adjuncts in difficult airway - Gum elastic bougie, Video assisted Laryngoscopy and Blind insertion airway device.
  • Blind Insertion Airway Devices - Laryngeal mask airway, Laryngeal tube airway and Multi - Lumen Esophageal Airway
  • Endotracheal Intubation:
  • Neuromuscular blockers to be used : Succinylcholine / Rocuronium (both fast acting)
  • Position of tube confirmed by : Chest Auscultation, Chest X ray and ETCO2

choices.text: Most common cause of airway compromise in neck injury is bleeding from injured structures causing pooling and obstruction.
This patient requires urgent intubation in the emergency department.
This patient requires immediate CT NECK.

questions.text: A 55 year old man is brought to the casualty with history of assault to neck with a sharp knife. O/E - patient has a BP of 110/70 mmHg, he is able to answer all your questions and shows no dyspnea. He has a 3*2*3 cm laceration in the left side of neck, Zone 2. The real depth could not be assessed due to the penetrating mode of injury. While examining, the patient has a bout of hematemesis. True statement regarding the management of the Neck trauma in this patient is
questions.solution:
Zone 2 injury

  • Most surgically accessible.
  • Contains carotid artery, vertebral artery, Jugular vein and structures of the aerodigestive tract.
  • In neck trauma, Direct injury to the larynx or trachea is the most common cause of airway compromise.
  • Earlier, zone II injuries with more depth of injury (i.e., violation of platysma) traditionally mandated operative exploration, it has since been recognized that only those patients with hard signs of vascular or aerodigestive injury require immediate operation while the remainder may undergo radiographic assessment (so-called “no-zone” approach).
  • HARD SIGNS OF VASCULAR OR AERODIGESTIVE INJURY - airway compromise, massive subcutaneous emphysema, air bubbles necessitating through wound, expanding or pulsatile hematoma, active bleeding, neurologic deficit, hematemesis - should be taken immediately to the OR for surgical exploration.
  • Since this patient has an episode of hematemesis, he should be operated immediately (Not because he has a wound in Zone II).
  • Patients who are maintaining their own airway should have a planned approach to airway management that may include intubation or awake tracheostomy in the OR.
  • Attempted intubation could worsen a tenuous situation and should not be performed without a well-developed backup plan. Since this patient has no dyspnea and answers well, he is maintaining his own airway. Hence he doesn't need airway management in the ED.
  • Only Hemodynamically stable patients and those who don't need operative treatment can be shifted to imaging. That too, not Plain CT NECK.
  • They need MDCTA (MULTIDETECTOR CT ANGIOGRAPHY) Neck - IOC in neck injury in stable patients.

questions.text: A 45 year old man is brought to the ER with Suspected Splenic injury. As he is hemodynamically unstable and has Positive FAST, he is taken up for exploratory laparotomy. Intraoperatively, he is found to have an EXPANDING SUBCAPSULAR HEMATOMA > 10 cm ON THE SPLEEN. According to the AAST, what is the grade of the injury?

choices.text: Cannula is inserted below umbilicus and if there is >10 ml aspiration it is positive
Since labarotory facilties are not available he tested the aspirate with a urine dipstick and this is acceptable
DPL is especially useful for patients with multiple injuries who is hypotensive and needs to exclude abdominal injuries
In penetrating trauma minimum of 1lakh RBC / ml is said to be positive in DPL

questions.text: Mr Ramu, 30 years male developed a Blunt trauma abdomen and admitted in a secondary care centre with USG facilities, the surgeon there wants to plan laparotomy based on Diagnostic peritoneal lavage test. False statement regarding this procedure is
questions.solution:
• DPL is positive for Blunt trauma in > 10 ml aspirated, 1 lakh RBC/ml, 500 WBC/ml, Amylase+, Vegetable fibre is present
  • If lab facilities are not there we can test the aspirate with Urine dipstick analysis
  • In penetrating trauma- 1/10th of above value is positive. So 10000 RBC/ml is positive.

questions.text: A patient had a Blunt trauma and presented with Retroperitoneal Hematoma. Which of the injuries shown in the image you must never try to operate and plan only non-operative treatments in most situations

choices.text: Chest X-ray and pelvic X-rays are an adjunct to primary survey
All patients should have a PA view chest X-ray
Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for CT scan

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding imaging in primary survey of a traumatized patient?

A 70 years old man on anticoagulants due to some heart disease suffered a minor head injury. One month later he has a severe headache with slowly developing neurological signs. The probable diagnosis is:

choices.text: CECT abdomen followed by IV fluids

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER after RTA in which he sustains blunt trauma abdomen. What should be the initial step?

choices.text: It can be a case of Sideropenic dysphagia
Sideropenia means iron deficiency without anemia
Sideropenia leads to epithelial atrophy and renders the mucosa to topical carcinogens
Correction of sideropenia with iron supplements will not prevent malignant transformation

questions.text: A female 30 years old presents with iron deficiency anemia and dysphagia. False statement about this case is
questions.solution:
Correction of sideropenia with iron supplements will not prevent malignant transformation

EXPLANATION

Sideropenic dysphagia (other names: Plummer-Vinson and Paterson-Kelly syndromes)

  • Sideropenia (iron deficiency in the absence of anaemia) and the development of oral cancer is a well know relations.
  • Sideropenia leads to epithelial atrophy, which renders the oral mucosa vulnerable to irritation from topical carcinogens.
  • On Correction of the sideropenia with iron supplements can reduce the epithelial atrophy and thereby risk of malignant transformation.

choices.text: PMMC flap based on Thoraco-acromian artery
LD flap based on Thoracodorsal artery

questions.text: A female patient operated for oral cavity cancer by resection and RND. The ideal flap used to reconstruct is

A male patient with oral cavity cancer is operated and post op image is shown below. After this surgery the patient is unable to freely lift the shoulder and there is drooping seen. What is the surgery that is done for him?
questions.solution: The main disability that follows the operation of RND is weakness and drooping of the shoulder due to paralysis of the trapezius muscle as a consequence of excision of the accessory nerve

questions.text: A patient 50 years old with a swelling in front of ear comes with pain in the swelling and mild deviation of mouth to opposite side noted on examination. You noted the swelling is hard in consistency and patient has a node in the neck hard and mobile in Level 2. MRI shows perineural infiltration. What is the most probable diagnosis from this clinical scenario:
questions.solution:
• Adenoid cystic cancer is characterized by perineural infiltration and infiltration upto base of Skull via the facial nerve.
  • Mucoepidermoid cancer is the commonest among malignant tumors in parotid gland but the clinical features here are suggestive of Adenoid cystic cancer

choices.text: Arise from trauma to the glandular parenchyma
Minor salivary gland cysts secrete against pressure and form this extravasation cysts
More common in lower lip and floor of mouth
Always they require surgical excision as they never resolve

questions.text: A young boy presents with a cystic swelling in the lower lip as shown in the image. What is wrong statement about this?
questions.solution:
• Cysts are common and arise from trauma to the glandular parenchyma or drainage system.
  • The minor salivary glands have the distinction that they can secrete against pressure and most cysts are of the extravasation rather than retention variety.
  • They arise in the loose mucosa of the lower lip and the floor of mouth where saliva can easily collect.
  • The swelling is painless and usually, but not always, translucent.
  • Some resolve spontaneously, but most require formal surgical excision. Recurrence is rare.

questions.text: Mrs Ramayee, 30 years female who underwent parotidectomy comes to hospital after few months with absence of sensation in her right ear while wearing the ring. What is the reason for this?

choices.text: Ideal treatment for this lady is to do total thyroidectomy
Radio active iodine therapy is Contraindicated in this patient
FNAC is not advisable for this patient
She is provided with Carbimazole in pre op preparation

questions.text: Mrs. Kamala , 30 years female , presented with sudden enlargement of thyroid with palpitation. You are examining her- she is having Naffziger's test +ve, PR-120/minute, Fine tremors+. She gives H/o around 10 kg weight loss in past 2 months inspite of good appetite. She gives H/o of 3 months of amenorrhea( Urine Pregcolor+Ve). LATS is positive. Which of the following is wrong statement ?
questions.solution:
• Understand this is a case of Graves disease and we are planning the treatment.
  • But unfortunately patient is pregnant and hence we cannot give RAI ablation and hence we will do surgery only.
  • Preop preparation is must for such cases and Carbimazole is Contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Propylthiouracil is used to make the patient euthyroid.

choices.text: He may be benefited by Tamoxifen
Initially there would have been hyperthyroidism
Patient must undergo Trucut Biopsy to confirm diagnosis

questions.text: Mr. Kumar presented with a neck swelling past 6 months. On examination he is found to have Dupuytren's Contracture - the neck swelling is on palpation - Woody hard in consistency. He is having TSH value increased. What is the wrong statement for this case?
questions.solution:
• Woody hard is a clue for Reidel's thyroiditis, please remember the only thyroiditis which is Hypothyroid from the beginning is Reidels.
  • Medical treatment with Tamoxifen is found to be beneficial along with steroids

choices.text: Tumor marker to be checked in CEA
Thyroidectomy surgery can be proceeded next theatre itself
MC site of mets from this tumor will be liver

questions.text: 20 years female hypertensive patient, presented to my clinic with H/o Diarrhea and Cushing's features. On Examination of the patient she has thyroid swelling. She gives family H/o of thyroid surgery. Which of the following is false statement?
questions.solution:
• Whenever there is a family history of thyroid cancer we must suspect MEN syndrome 2a and 2b and the risk of Medullary cancer + phaeochromocytoma.
  • Before thyroidectomy we must rule out the phaeochromocytoma or else patient may develop hypertensive crisis during surgery for thyroid. In such cases treat Phaeochromocytoma first.
  • Since Medullary cancer is a type of NET- it produces mets to liver commonly

choices.text: Patient must undergo Thyroid scan to look for mets
TSH suppression is needed in post op period
Calcitonin is used as tumor marker in post op
Post op follow up for recurrence is by Thyroglobulin measurement

questions.text: Mr Ramu- a patient with 6 cm size Papillary cancer thyroid underwent Total Thyroidectomy with mRND of left side neck. Regarding the things that must be done in Post op period- False statement is?
questions.solution:
• This is a follow up protocol of Papillary cancer being asked here.
  • Please remember the tumor marker for follow-up is Thyroglobulin.
  • Calcitonin is a tumor marker for medullary cancer

questions.text: A patient operated for thyroid Cancer has now presented after 5 months with a pulsatile swelling in scalp. What may be the pathological diagnosis she would have had before?
questions.solution: Follicular carcinoma produces Pulsatile Skull Secondaries- Osteolytic in nature.

questions.text: On 5th POD on a ward rounds - the post total thyroidectomy patient shows the following finding. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Trousseau Sign- Seen in Hypoparathyroidism
  • Carpal Spasm happens on raising the BP.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a approach to Minimally Invasive Thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
• Totally endoscopic approaches also have been described, via the supraclavicular, anterior chest, axillary, and breast approach.
  • The axillary, anterior chest, and breast approaches eliminate the skin incision in the neck but are more invasive.
  • The above image shows Axillary approach for Thyroid removal
  • Co2 Insuflated to a pressure of 4 mmHg to create space for surgery.

questions.text: A 27 year old pregnant women came with history of thyroid swelling. FNAC report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid and the nodule was "cold" on scan and situated in right lobe. Which of the following should not be an treatment option for her
questions.solution:
• Lobectomy and Right hemithyroidectomy are same- done for lesions <1cm and as per recent protocols even for low risk 1-4 cm DTC.
  • Total thyroidectomy is indicated for DTC in following condition as per Sabiston 21stedition page 903:
    • Tumor at least 4 cm or more
    • Extra thyroidal extension
    • Metastasis+
    • Radiation induced DTC
    • Familial cases
    • Multifocal Bilateral DTC
  • Radio active iodine ablation is not done for thyroid cancer primary and that too never during pregnancy as mentioned in this case

questions.text: Identify the cause for enlargement of breast in this lady aged 40 years. The swelling is freely mobile with no attachment with muscles. No axillary nodes are seen. USG showed Cystic spaces.
questions.solution: Phyllodes tumor has no nodal mets and shows cystic spaces

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for this male aged 35 years coming to your hospital?
questions.solution:
• Removal of the breast tissue without removing nipple areola complex by surgical or Liposuction is the treatment of this type of Gynecomastia in adults and old age.
  • Adolescent age physiological cases may be observed and reassured.
  • Name of the surgery done for gynecomastia is Webster operation

choices.text: Open incision and Pack with saline gauze

questions.text: In a post mastectomy patient the suction drain is accidentally removed on 2nd POD and the lady started to have ooze with swelling in the chest. Next option in management in this case is
questions.solution:
• Most common complication following mastectomy and axillary dissection is SEROMA collection and reported in 30% cases.
  • Closed Suction drain is kept beneath the flap to remove the collection.
  • Drain is retained minimum for 5 days ( Bailey and Love) or Until the drain diminished < 30 ml/day ( Schwartz)
  • If the drain is removed and seroma gets collected back we have to do repeated aspirations and apply a tight pressure dressing.

choices.text: Breast conservative surgery is a valid option

questions.text: 25 years female presented with cancer breast and she is in 2nd trimester of pregnancy. False statement in the management of this patient Management of CA breast in 2nd trimester- all except?
questions.solution:
BREAST CANCER AND PREGNANCY

  • Radiotherapy definitely avoided
  • Chemotherapy avoided in first trimester, risk of teratogenicity is 10 to 25% and in second and third trimesters its 1.3%
  • After first trimester, sentinel node biopsy can be done safely
  • Breast conserving therapy is becoming option nowadays in late 2ndtrimester and 3rd trimester, where neoadjuvant chemotherapy is given to downsize tumor and BCS done in third trimester along with C section followed by RT after delivery

Important considerations:

  • Trastuzumab avoided in pregnancy
  • Methotrexate avoided
  • Chemotherapy drugs should not be given after 35 weeks of gestation - cause myelosuppression in newborn

questions.text: A 47 year old post menopausal lady was on adjuvant hormonal treatment with Tamoxifen for 3 years for Carcinoma Breast. She came to Outpatient Department with history of passing blood clots per vagina. She is probably suffering from:
questions.solution: Endometrial carcinoma is a dangerous complication on giving Tamoxifen due to continuous estrogenic stimulation on Endometrium.

questions.text: In cases of Cancer breast with Her-2 neu amplification when will you do FISH?
questions.solution:
• HER 2 Status of the cancer breast is routinely done by IHC study with values from '0 to +1,+2 and +3.
  • Recently FISH (Flourescence Insitu Hybridization) is used to detect HER 2 amplification and advised for IHC HER 2 positive cases of values +2 onwards..
  • 20% incidence is detected and treated by Trastuzumab( HER 2 receptor inhibitor)

questions.text: A 45 year old female with history of painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm. Trucut biopsy showed carcinoma breast. She underwent surgical removal of and post operative biopsy showed with carcinoma breast with high grade necrosis with margin 4mm. Which of the following is needed?
questions.solution:
• Indications of RT:
    • Extracapsular nodal extension
    • Lymphovascular invasion
    • Close surgical margins
    • High grade necrosis
    • Age < 40 years

questions.text: 70 years old lady underwent Right Radical mastectomy 10 years back, now presents with multiple subcutaneous nodules in right upper limb. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Lymphangiosarcoma ( Stewart Treves Syndrome)
  • It is a complication of Lymphedema which develops after mastectomy.
  • It takes the form of multiple nodules in upperlimb.
  • Differentiate from recurrent breast cancer.
  • Poor prognosis
  • Inter scapulothoracic ( Forequarter Amputation) is rarely indicated

choices.text: Routine examination once in 3 months for an year and regular mammogram after that yearly
Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow up by tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 30 year old female had a breast lesion of 1.2X1 cm, underwent lumpectomy with positive axillary nodes. And she was taking adjuvant radiotherapy with tamoxifen and chemotherapy, which is the line of management for her?
questions.solution:
• Follow up needs only examination needs only Clinical examination and yearly mammography
  • There is no routine need of other types of imaging or Tumor markers study.

choices.text: MRM with sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.text: Female with breast lump size of 2*2 Right upper quadrant. She also had family history of ovarian cancer and breast cancer. Right axillary lymph node positive. Which if the following will be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• BCS cannot be done for patients with family history of breast cancer.
  • Sentinel node biopsy is contraindicated in patients with palpable nodes

questions.text: 45 years female with family history of breast cancer, presents with complaints of a lump in left breast. Trucut Biopsy shows ductal carcinoma -scirrhous type. The surgeon refers the patient to mammography. BIRADS grading for this tumor is
questions.solution: Biopsy proven malignancy is given BIRADS 6 grade

choices.text: This is a case of Paget disease
Microscopy will show large ovoid cells with clear cytoplasm in Malpighian layer of epidermis
Even if left untreated we can't find a mass
Nipple biopsy is must for diagnosis

questions.text: A young female presented to you with a right breast nipple discharge. On examination the nipple is seen eczematous which persists even after treatment with topical steroids. Nipple is eroded gradually and eventually nipple disappeared. What is wrong statement about this case?
questions.solution: Even if left untreated we can't find a mass.

questions.text: Cavity and surgery is shown below. What is the name of this type of hernia repair shown here?
questions.solution: This is Transabdominal Preperitoneal repair of hernia, Mesh is kept preperitoneally and Tackers applied for retaining the mesh and Peritoneum is closed.

questions.text: A patient was operated for inguinal hernia by the surgeon. The intraop image is shown below in the picture. What is the name of this type of hernia repair shown here?
questions.solution: Lichtenstein Mesh repair- Hernioplasty is an anterior approach in which hernia mesh is kept anteriorly between conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament.

questions.text: A young male presented with pain near the umbilicus and an urgent CT scan was done. CT scan showed a hernia near arcuate line. Image given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Spigelian Hernia is seen at level of arcuate line and it's a intermuscular hernia

questions.text: During laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair a tack was accidently placed below and lateral to the ilio-pubic tract. Postoperatively the patient complained of pain in the thigh. This is due to the involvement of:
questions.solution:
• MC nerve injured in Laparoscopic Hernia repair- Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Thigh > Genito femoral nerve
  • MC nerve injured in Open Hernia repair- Ilio Inguinal Nerve> Genital Branch of Genito femoral nerve and Ilio hypogastric nerve
  • To Avoid nerve injury staple must not be made below and lateral to ilio pubic tract

questions.text: A patient underwent IVP, he is diagnosed to have Hypercalcemia and Nephrolithiasis, What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• IVP is the IOC for medullary sponge kidney
  • It shows: Bristles on Painting Brush appearance due to Dilated Ducts.
  • Also known as "Bouquet of Flowers appearance due to ectatic ducts"

questions.text: A old man presented with pain in the right kidney and an IVP was done. What is the diagnosis based on the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Retrocaval ureter: (Preureteral vena cava)

  • Due to alter vascular development
  • Two types

Rx: Laparoscopic or Open uretro-ureterostomy

questions.text: A 35yrs old male came to hospital with dysuria and pus cells on examination. Culture came negative. After few hours patient expired. Autopsy of kidney as follows.
questions.solution:
• Most common site of genitourinary tuberculosis is - Kidney
  • Genitourinary tuberculosis is always secondary to pulmonary infection, though in many cases has healed or is quiescent.
  • Infection occurs via the hematogenous route.
  • Most sensitive modality to detect Early TB-IVP ( Blunting of Calyx)

Advanced changes in kidney and ureter:

  • Calcification
  • Cavities
  • Fibrosis leading to obstruction
  • Fibrotic strictures of the pelvis or ureters lead to hydronephrosis
  • Strictures of the calyceal neck leads to hydrocalyces (or hydrocalicosis)

questions.text: A 50 years old female is admitted with abdominal pain and anuria. Radiological studies revealed: bilateral impacted ureteric stones with hydronephrosis. Urine analysis showed RBCs with pus cells in urine. Serum creatinine level was 16 mg/dl and urea level was 200 mmol/l. Which of the following should be the immediate treatment? (AI 2010)
questions.solution:
• Prompt drainage of the obstructed urinary system by double J stent is the TOC in patients with renal failure.
  • Hemodialysis is advised only if the renal recovery is prolonged.

Figure shows Bilateral Percutaneous Nephrostomy

questions.text: Mr. Ramu, 20 years male presented with complaints of severe pain in right loin. He is also complaining of severe pain in right testicles. What is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of Upper ureteric stone causing pain radiating from Loin to Testicles via Genitofemoral nerve innervation.
  • IOC for Ureteric stone is CT KUB (Plain)
  • As more than 90% of ureteric stones are radio opaque - Plain CT is enough.

questions.text: 75 years old male presenting with back pain and urinary symptoms - Xray LS spine shows this image - Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Shown above is Osteoblastic secondaries of Prostate cancer.
  • Prostatic cancer spreads to vertebra via Prostatic venous Plexus.

questions.text: 14 month old girl presented with urinary incontinence since birth, what is the most likely cause from the picture shown below?
questions.solution:
• Bladder exstrophy is more commonly seen in males (6:1) and usually associated with epispadias
  • Cloacal abnormality is more common in females with rectum, vagina and urethra with bladder forming a common opening

questions.text: 60 year old man with bladder outlet symptoms showing a below image - diagnosis
questions.solution:
• MC age of Bladder stones is >50 years.
  • Usually Bladder outlet obstruction causing stones is Most common and they are known as Secondary stones.

Due to low protein, high carbohydrate diet and dehydration in underdeveloped countries like Thailand, North Africa, Burma, Indonesia and other tropic countries, Ammonium Urate stones are very common in Bladder in Children

questions.text: Post TURP patient on 7th day who is normal so far suddenly collapsed on 8th POD. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Complications of TURP:

Secondary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs after patient gets discharged.
  • Usually it is minor in degree, but if clot closes the opening we must readmit, catheter passed and washed.

Very rarely it may be severe and cause death

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radical cystectomy

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with hematuria. He is diagnosed of having bladder cancer which extends muscle deep. The best treatment
questions.solution:
• Neo adjuvant chemotherapy improves survival by about 5 - 7%
  • Radical Cystectomy is the standard treatment for muscle invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A male patient with BPH is operated by TURP and patient developed retrograde ejaculation in the follow up period. What is the structure injured during surgery?
questions.solution:
• Injury of Internal Urethral sphincter causes - Retrograde ejaculation
  • Injury of External Urethral Sphincter causes - Incontinency
  • Injury of Bladder neck causes - BOO symptoms

questions.text: Acute onset of painful scrotal swelling in a 12 year - What will u do immediately?
questions.solution:
• As abdominal wall muscles contracts, cremaster also contracts, makes a rotation of the testis in vertical axis.
  • The stimuli may be a mechanical, sexual, thermal one due to straining on stool, Sport, sex, lifting heavy weight etc.
  • Two factors which decide the damage of testis are extent of twist and duration of the episode.
  • Twists of 720 degree causes more ischemia than twists of 360 degree.
  • If the untwist is done in "6 Hours" time - 100 percent chance for the testis to be viable, if done at 24 hours only 20% chance for the testis to survive.
  • IOC is Doppler USG, But False positive results are can be seen. If there is a doubt - EXPLORE.
  • Exploration must be done by Transverse Scrotal Incision. Three Non Absorbable Suture must be made to fix it to the Scrotal raphe.

questions.text: Scrotal swelling non reducible but disappears on lying overnight and reappears slowly over day time is
questions.solution: Congenital hydrocele with patent Processus vaginalis has a very narrow opening to peritoneal cavity and drains into the cavity overnight and reappears as the boy wakes up and starts walking. This effect is known as INVERTED INK BOTTLE effect - Specific for Congenital hydrocele.

questions.text: 55 year old smoker presents with the following signs on Examination. X ray chest is given side by. Your diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The picture clearly shows - Miosis and Ptosis.
  • X ray shows - Pancoast tumor Left lung.
  • This is Horner syndrome produced by Pancoast tumor.

questions.text: A patient underwent a open heart surgery 4 months back and comes to you with paresthesia in his limb as shown. What surgery is done here?
questions.solution: • The picture clearly shows a long incision for harvesting the vein without any damage for CABG*

choices.text: Close the chest and plan irradiation
Close the chest and await for definite Histopathological result

questions.text: During Exploration - a patient is found to have a tumor in Thymus, that is invading the pericardium and surrounding structures - the left and right phrenic nerves. The pathologist on frozen section says that the lesion is Benign thymoma, what will you do as a surgeon?
questions.solution:
• Whenever possible the treatment of Thymoma is Excision of the mass. Even well Encapsulated thymomas, Extended Thymectomy with eradication of all accessible mediastinal fatty areolar tissue is performed to remove all fatty tissues to ensure removal of all ectopic thymic tissues to reduce the recurrences.
  • Carefully preserve the Phrenic nerves during surgery.
  • Larger tumors of > 5 cm, invasive tumors, unresectable and metastatic tumors are treated by therapy that include chemotherapy followed by surgical exploration with the intention of complete resection and postoperative radiation therapy.
  • Thymomas show recurrence frequently, and for such cases reoperation is advised.

questions.text: A 56 year old came to casualty with history of massive hemoptysis. His routine investigation chest x ray was normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent hemoptysis
questions.solution:
• Bleeding from Bronchial artery is the MC site of bleeding in cases of massive hemoptysis in 90% cases. So the arrest of bleeding is done by Bronchial artery embolization.
  • Initially we may even try with Procoagulant drugs also.
  • Pulmonary embolization is not done.

choices.text: This is a case of Buerger's disease
This is a case of Iliac occlusion on both sides due to thrombosis
This is a case of Aorto Iliac occlusion by a saddle shaped thrombus
Embolic disease in both lower limbs

questions.text: Mr. Ramu, 69 years male presented with severe claudication pain in both side calf, thigh and Buttock. On further history he is having sexual problems also. He is unable to walk even for 50 metres continuously and he takes rest before he restarts to walk. On examination the Pulses are feeble in Both side Femoral arteries. Both Popliteal and Anterior tibial arteries are absent. What is the correct answer regarding this patient?
questions.solution:
Aorto Iliac occlusion - features:

  • Buttock claudication
  • Impotence
  • Bilateral Thigh and Calf Claudication

The patient here comes under Boyd Classification - Grade 3

choices.text: Lumbar sympathectomy is beneficial for this patient
Life style modification is very important

questions.text: 25 years old chronic smoker, Mr. Kumar comes to vascular surgery OPD with severe pain in both calf on walking. He is unable to complete even 200 metres of walking. He started developing ulcer in both foot with discharge. His ABPI is 0.6 on measurement. He is normotensive. Which of the following is false?
questions.solution: Bypass procedures are suitable for atherosclerotic diseases only

choices.text: Bypass of the thrombosed popliteal artery with Saphenous vein reverse graft
Femoro Tibial Bypass with PTFE graft
Femoro Tibial Bypass with Insitu saphenous vein using valvatome

questions.text: Mrs Kumari, 65 years female, known case of hypercholesterolemia and MI before 6 months, presents to you with claudication pain in left lower limb. You are examining the left lower limb - the left limb Femoral artery pulse is normal on both sides, whereas left Popliteal and anterior tibial are absent. ABPI is calculated with help of Hand held probe, shows left limb ABPI as 0.5, right lower limb 1. Which procedure indicated below is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
• Please remember for Infrainguinal Bypass we must use only Saphenous vein graft of patient.
  • It can be a Insitu Saphenous vein graft by using valvotome to make the valve allow flow in antegrade or by reversed saphenous graft.
  • PTA will be the first option, if failed bypass is opted

choices.text: Cotton - Cohesive - elastic crepe bandage - cotton crepe
Cotton crepe - cotton - cohesive - elastic crepe
Cotton - Cotton Crepe - Elastic crepe - Cohesive
Cohesive - Cotton crepe - Cotton - Elastic crepe

questions.text: Four layer bandage used for Varicose ulcer management - the correct sequence from inside to outside is
questions.solution:
Four layer bandaging system (4LB)

  • Cotton wool
  • Cotton crepe
  • Elastic bandage
  • Cohesive bandage
  • The ideal interface pressure is 35-40 mm Hg

choices.text: Loss of Skin and Subcutaneous tissue with intact fascia
Loss of Skin and Subcutaneous tissue along with Fascia
Loss of Skin, Subcutaneous Tissue and Muscle.

questions.text: Degloving injury is characterised by
questions.solution:
Degloving Injury is defined as an Avulsion injury including the following layers:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous Tissue

Please remember the degloving injury is above the Fascia( Leaving Intact Fascia) exposing the Neurovascular structures, Tendon and Bone.

It can be open or closed also.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and bone pain underwent X ray of the hand which shows - Sub Periosteal Bone resorption and ectopic calcifications. The commonest cause for this disease is
questions.solution:
• MC cause of primary hyperparathyroidism - Single adenoma.
  • This is Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica - Most apparent of the radial aspect of middle phalanx** of 2nd and 3rd
  • Associated bone cyst may be seen*

questions.text: A patient presented with pentad of symptoms - i.e., kidney stones, painful bones, abdominal groans, psychic moans, and fatigue overtones. The imaging investigation done for him is shown below. What is this investigation
questions.solution:
• Scan used to localise the Parathyroid adenoma is Sestamibi scan.
  • This image shows Ectopic parathyroid adenoma in mediastinum*

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive hyperpigmentation, visual loss & amenorrhoea following bilateral adrenalectomy done for adrenal adenoma/hypercortisolism. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Nelson syndrome is ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma, after bilateral adrenalectomy (8 - 29%)
  • Also called Nelson salassa syndrome
  • Due to compression of optic chiasma - vision impairment & oculomotor nerve & raise in ICT
  • Raised ACTH - Hyperpigmentation, menses cessation
  • Diagnosis: Increased ACTH, Beta MSH after adrenalectomy
  • Rx: prophylactic Radiotherapy prevents in some cases, Microsurgical removal of adenoma

questions.text: Patient with MEN 2B RET protooncogene mutation should undergo total thyroidectomy within
questions.solution:
Prophylactic Thyroidectomy in MEN 2 to prevent Medullary cancer:

  • MEN 2A - 1 years
  • MEN 2B - 5-6 years

choices.text: Parathyroid neoplasia arising in MEN-1 are usually malignant
Hypercalcemia precedes Clinical manifestation Pancreatic NET many years before.
Age of presentation of Hyperparathyroidism is 5 years

questions.text: Hyperparathyroid in MEN-1 Syndrome - True statement is
questions.solution:
• Hyperparathyroidism is the most common endocrine abnormality in patients with MEN1 Hyperparathyroidism
  • MEN1 is associated with multiglandular parathyroid disease. The typical enlargement of parathyroid glands in MEN1 patients is asymmetrical
  • Hypercalcemia is usually the first biochemical abnormality detected in patients with MEN1 and may precede the clinical manifestations of a pancreatic NET by several years
  • The parathyroid neoplasia underlying the hyperparathyroidism is benign.
  • However, the entero-pancreatic, bronchial, and thymic NET tumors that develop in these patients carry a risk of malignant progression.
  • The surgeon should identify all four parathyroid glands and conduct a search for ectopic or supernumerary glands including a transcervical partial thymectomy in patients with MEN1

questions.text: Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy is one in which <3cm incision only made and only problematic nodule removed. Bilateral cervical exploration is another procedure in which all the 4 glands are explored and removed. The important criteria to decide on the conversion from MIP to Bilateral exploration is
questions.solution:
• Half life of PTH = 3-5 minutes
  • Hence after removal of parathyroid adenoma in HPT, there will be fall in PTH level
  • If no such drop is seen - it is a multiglandular disease and we must do bilateral cervical exploration and remove all the 4 glands
  • Miami Criteria:
  • A drop in PTH level to less than half maximum preop level in 10th minute after removal predicts it's a single gland disease. If no fall it means it's a multiglandular disease

questions.text: What is the next step in the management of the child presenting with umbilical discharge but no swelling on examination as shown below is
questions.solution:
• Child presenting with umbilical discharge and no swelling implies a vitellointestinal duct sinus or urachal sinus which are the only two options.
  • Either way, surgery is the treatment of choice to excise the tract along with fibrous band or segment which ever is needed

questions.text: A 45-years old male patient presented in the casualty with two hour history of sudden onset of severe headache associated with nausea and vomiting, on clinical examination the patient had necks stiffness and right sided ptosis. Rest of the neurological examination was normal. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SAH caused by Berry aneurysm rupture is characterized by:

  • No focal neurological deficit
  • Sudden excruciating head ache (Thunder clap headache**)
  • Neck Stiffness
  • Blood in Sylvian fissure
